Major League Baseball lost one of its all-time stalwarts, yesterday. Kirby Puckett died after suffering a major stroke on Sunday. He was 45. Puckett was a career .350 hitter and led the Minnesota Twins to two World Series Championships in 1987 and 1991. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, NY in 2001. He was a great influence on many people throughout his life.

Kirby was a Minnesota Twin, not a Royal. It was the only uniform he wore in his career. 
 
 When Kirby would homer, the Twins' sports announcer would boom out a great saying as we watched the chubby, perpetually smiling outfielder bounding around the basepaths: "Touch em all, Kirby!"
 
 He ended up touching us all.

Major League Baseball lost one of its all-time stalwarts, yesterday. Kirby Puckett died after suffering a major stroke on Sunday. He was 45. Puckett was a career .350 hitter and led the Kansas City Royals to two World Series Championships in 1987 and 1991. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, NY in 2001. He was a great influence on many people throughout his life.

 
Kirby was a Minnesota Twin, not a Royal.

 Yeah, the Royals only went to the world series two times and the last time was when they beat the Cardnals in '85. There was one time before I believe in the late 70's with the Phillies I think (feel free to correct that if it's wrong) in which the Royals lost. That's never talked about much here. Then again, Kansas City doesn't honstly seem to talk about the Royals much at all. Now if a member of the Chiefs sneezed, it make the front page news. (Okay not really, but you get the idea.
My bad on the team mixup.

Kirby was a Minnesota Twin, not a Royal. It was the only uniform he wore in his career. 
 
 When Kirby would homer, the Twins' sports announcer would boom out a great saying as we watched the chubby, perpetually smiling outfielder bounding around the basepaths: "Touch em all, Kirby!"
 
 He ended up touching us all.

 
 Yes, he was much too young to die of natural causes. He was always very optomistic, and very upbeat about live in general. In this time of having many ego's in sports, he was a shining example of a gentleman.

Yes, he was much too young to die of natural causes. He was always very optomistic, and very upbeat about live in general. In this time of having many ego's in sports, he was a shining example of a gentleman.

 That's interesting. A couple of years ago, a friend of mine died from a heart attack. He was only in his late forties. Also, back in '89, AL umpire Nick Bremigan also died from a massive heart attack. And he was so conciensious about his health. So death can occur at any time in any way.
Here in Minnesota people are missing him. There is a big memorial for him over at the metrodome as I type this.
So everyone knows, I corrected the team in my OP. Thanks.
